questions.neutral: Is it always this quiet when you come in?

hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Typewriters treating you better than people?
Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Quieter than usual, yes. I mostly fix old typewriters these days. Not much use for them except when the city’s loud. Hard to focus lately with all the assemblies nearby.
Evenings are usually like this, I suppose. I restore typewriters—keeps my hands busy. The last few weeks, all the noise outside makes it slow going. Not everyone appreciates the quiet work.

Quieter than the square, certainly. I collect and repair antique typewriters—a peculiar pastime now. Street debates tend to drift in, threw me off my last project. I had to pause—too many raised voices, even for an old Hermes. Still, it’s steadier work than most these days.

It’s often quiet when I’m here, which I prefer. My hobby is restoring typewriters—Hermes, Underwood, you name it. Last week, the free zone council held a truth assembly right outside my window. Crowds argued, details spilled—hard to focus on fine springs and dusty keys. Sometimes the world seeps in, even into small repairs.

Used to be quieter, before the assemblies took over the streets. I’ve spent years restoring old typewriters—Hermes 3000 is my favorite for the carriage design. Sometimes I draft memories on paper, keep journals—habit from before BCI took hold. Last Thursday, the assembly outside broke my routine; I documented voices and arguments as much as machine repairs. These days, both seem equally fragile—old metal and honest testimony. It’s strange how hobbies blur with history lately.
hobby_answer: Managed to find one old ribbon, barely usable.
Typewriter runs, but street noise complicates repairs lately.
Crowds outside, truth assemblies and such.
Hard to focus on old machines these days.
Things change.
Picked up a faded ribbon, does the job—in a fashion.
Working on a Hermes 3000, keeps me busy.
Harder now, since the assemblies spill over halfway up the block.
All this document sharing. People wave paper, not much care for accuracy.
Feels like my quiet projects are everyone else's business these days.
Yes, managed to get a half-decent ribbon last week.
Restored an old typewriter—green, cracked spacebar, from Council storage.
Was fixing it during the truth assembly outside my flat.
Difficult not to get distracted—all those voices debating BCI records.
Odd feeling, the analog clack against digital chaos on the square.
Even my repair notes now blend with crowd noise.
World outside invades the keys, whether I like it or not.
Found a ribbon through an old contact—took some favors, but still works.
Spent hours this week on that Hermes, stubborn little carriage spring.
Truth assembly in the square made it tricky—arguments, forged records, whole mess.
I used to repair for focus, now street debates drown out every keypress.
People with lists, testimonies, seeking 'evidence'—but nobody cares for logic in the noise.
I find myself noting both typewriter faults and crowd reactions, all jumbled together.
Strange overlap of the private and public now.
My repairs have become half craft, half witness to these times.
Secured a proper typewriter ribbon, thanks to an old archivist's favor.
Mechanical work calms me—was restoring the Hermes during the last neighborhood assembly.
The voices downstairs, raw and desperate. BCI records read aloud to strangers.
Impossible to keep focused, every keystroke blurred by stories of injustice.
Used to be just me, keys, and paper. Now, half the city listens in.
Lately, I document not only machine repairs, but who shouts, who listens, what changes.
It reminds me of council meetings—quiet leaks, loud denials, always someone rewriting truth.
Typewriters leave no digital trace. Maybe that's why I hold on tighter now.
Even these small rituals feel subversive, with everything spilling out in the open.
